titleStmt.title: Cynicism as Immanent Critique: Diogenes and the Philosophy of Transvaluation

analytic.title: Cynicism as Immanent Critique: Diogenes and the Philosophy of Transvaluation

monogr.title: Polis: The Journal for Ancient Greek and Roman Political Thought
Polis

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: I argue that Diogenes and early Cynicism can be understood in an explicitly social and political context, where Cynic praxis, performative public action, can be seen to make visible oppositions inherent to the polity. In doing so, Diogenes' praxis should be understood as a form of immanent critique, one that demonstrates, for example, that nature and custom (phusis and nomos) are interrelated oppositions in the polis. Cynicism here is understood as a form of immanent critique because Diogenes challenges the social norms of the polis without endorsing external universal standards or predetermined models, but from illuminating dynamics from within the polis and polity.
